'''Joseph Lunardi''' (AKA Joey Brackets) is a college [[basketball]] analyst for [[ESPN]]. He was born in [[Philadelphia]], he is a graduate of [[Damien High School]] in La Verne, California (valedictorian 1978), and is a [[Saint Joseph's University]] alumnus. Lunardi currently lives in [[Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania]]. He is best known for creating [[Bracketology]], which he calls the "art and science" of predicting the teams that will be selected in the annual [[NCAA]] Men's Basketball Tournament. He is well-known as the resident bracketologist for ESPN. In addition to his duties at ESPN, he is the Assistant Vice President of Marketing Communications at [[Saint Joseph's University]] and does color commentary for men's basketball for the [[Saint Joseph's Hawks]]. Lunardi correctly predicted all 65 teams to appear in the [[2008 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2008 NCAA Tournament]].,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/17/sports/ncaabasketball/17notebook.html | title=Big East Stands Tallest With 8 Bids | author=Evans, Thayer | date=March 17, 2008 | accessdate=2009-03-15 | work=The New York Times}}</ref> while correctly selecting 63 out the 65 teams in the [[2009 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2009 field]] by placing both Creighton and St. Mary's incorrectly in his final bracket on March 15.<ref>http://insider.espn.go.com/ncb/insider/news/story?id=3981856&&appRedirect=http%3a%2f%2finsider.espn.go.com%2fncb%2finsider%2fnews%2fstory%3fid%3d3981856</ref> Lunardi correctly selected 64 of the 65 teams in the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2010 NCAA Tournament]], believing that Illinois would receive the final at-large bid, while in reality, Florida did.<ref>http://espn.go.com/blog/collegebasketballnation/post/_/id/6992/bracket-winners-and-losers</ref>
+
'''Joseph Lunardi''' (AKA Joey Brackets) is a college [[basketball]] analyst for [[ESPN]]. He was born in [[Philadelphia]], he is a graduate of [[Haverford High School]] in Pennsylvania, and is a [[Saint Joseph's University]] alumnus. Lunardi currently lives in [[Drexel Hill, Pennsylvania]]. He is best known for creating [[Bracketology]], which he calls the "art and science" of predicting the teams that will be selected in the annual [[NCAA]] Men's Basketball Tournament. He is well-known as the resident bracketologist for ESPN. In addition to his duties at ESPN, he is the Assistant Vice President of Marketing Communications at [[Saint Joseph's University]] and does color commentary for men's basketball for the [[Saint Joseph's Hawks]]. Lunardi correctly predicted all 65 teams to appear in the [[2008 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2008 NCAA Tournament]].,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/17/sports/ncaabasketball/17notebook.html | title=Big East Stands Tallest With 8 Bids | author=Evans, Thayer | date=March 17, 2008 | accessdate=2009-03-15 | work=The New York Times}}</ref> while correctly selecting 63 out the 65 teams in the [[2009 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2009 field]] by placing both Creighton and St. Mary's incorrectly in his final bracket on March 15.<ref>http://insider.espn.go.com/ncb/insider/news/story?id=3981856&&appRedirect=http%3a%2f%2finsider.espn.go.com%2fncb%2finsider%2fnews%2fstory%3fid%3d3981856</ref> Lunardi correctly selected 64 of the 65 teams in the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2010 NCAA Tournament]], believing that Illinois would receive the final at-large bid, while in reality, Florida did.<ref>http://espn.go.com/blog/collegebasketballnation/post/_/id/6992/bracket-winners-and-losers</ref>
Lunardi's first bracket for ESPN received 250,000 hits in the first 90 minutes posted. His brackets sometimes receive millions of hits over the course of a season.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/03/AR2007030300980_pf.html | title=Need for Information Is Creating a Bracket | author=Prisbell, Eric | date=March 4, 2007 | accessdate=2009-03-15 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Since then, he has been a fixture on ESPN's ''Bracketology'' program and on ''[[SportsCenter]]'', especially during the months of February and March in the run-up to the NCAA Tournament.<ref>http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/bracketology</ref>
Lunardi's first bracket for ESPN received 250,000 hits in the first 90 minutes posted. His brackets sometimes receive millions of hits over the course of a season.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/03/03/AR2007030300980_pf.html | title=Need for Information Is Creating a Bracket | author=Prisbell, Eric | date=March 4, 2007 | accessdate=2009-03-15 | work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Since then, he has been a fixture on ESPN's ''Bracketology'' program and on ''[[SportsCenter]]'', especially during the months of February and March in the run-up to the NCAA Tournament.<ref>http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/bracketology</ref>
